Award.AwardTitle: Control of Protein Dimerization through Light-Regulated Rapamycin
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Alexander Deiters of the University of Pittsburgh to develop a new type of molecular "glue" that can be used to bind together two molecules of protein and, thus, control a variety of biological functions. The new type of "glue" being developed in this research project is similar to a naturally occurring substance known as rapamycin that has been extensively used to bind pairs of proteins. The new substance differs from rapamycin since it has a light-sensitive switch. This switch allows the investigators to turn on and off the protein-binding process at will, producing a powerful new tool. This research is opening up a wide variety of possible new applications that would potentially have a broad impact on a number of biological and medical fields of study. The investigators are further broadening the impact of their work by partnering with a children's museum to develop demonstrations and exhibits that bring basic biological events, especially those involving the interaction of ultraviolet light with tissues, to life for young children and their parents.

In this project, the investigators are developing light-responsive rapamycin analogs for the optical control of protein dimerization and other cellular processes. Rapamycin is a commonly applied biomolecular tool that has been used to control a wide range of physiological processes. An extensive number of cellular functions have been brought under its control, including transcription, signal transduction, protein localization, enzyme activation, protein splicing, protein secretion, and protein post-translational modification in cells. Rapamycin functions as a small molecule inducer of protein dimerization by recruiting FKBP and FRB to form a stable ternary complex. A versatile and generally applicable light-regulation methodology that is adaptable to numerous biological applications is being developed by designing and synthesizing light-sensitive analogs of rapamycin. Light represents an innovative external control element, since a) it is orthogonal to the vast majority of cellular processes, b) it is minimally invasive, and c) it can be controlled with very high spatial and temporal resolution. Light-activated analogs of rapamycin, in conjunction with different proteins fused to FKBP and FRB, will enable the optical regulation of a wide range of cellular processes, including protein function, protein localization, and protein association. Completion of the research objectives will lead to 1) the development of orthogonal caged rapamycin-FKBP pairs for the multi-wavelength activation of multiple cellular processes, and 2) the reversible light-switching of biological processes through rapamycin analogs modified with photo-switchable motifs. Expected outcomes of the proposed research are a unifying approach for the spatio-temporal control of various cellular processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In order to perform required biochemical reactions, proteins and enzymes inside a cell must interact in a highly coordinated manner. The activity of these proteins or enzymes is often modulated by specific interactions with other proteins, and can result in activation or deactivation of a protein’s function. In order to control and study the effects of protein-protein interactions within cells, chemical biologists have developed tools that enable the rapid association of two proteins of interest. The most commonly used system utilizes FKBP and FRB fused to the two proteins of interest, such that upon addition of the small molecule rapamycin, FKBP and FRB dimerize and bring the two proteins of interest in close proximity to each other. Researchers have extensively utilized this tool to study the effects of natural and artificial protein-protein interactions for improved understanding of cellular functions. However, once dimerized, the FKBP-rapamycin-FRB interaction is like “molecular glue” and the proteins generally remain stuck together. Since cellular interactions are dynamic in nature (meaning proteins interact, then dissociate, then interact with other proteins), it would be ideal to have tools that can mimic this type of behavior. In this project we developed methods to control the activity of rapamycin using light exposure to induce a cellular response. Three subgroups of rapamycin analogs were developed: light activatable, light deactivatable, and reversibly controlled. 

 

Our lab has previously developed ultraviolet light activated analogs of rapamycin, but a drawback of that technology is the potential for toxicity from ultraviolet light. Thus, we developed a rapamycin analog that is capable of being activated with visible light (415 nm). Furthermore, we designed and synthesized a series of reversibly controlled rapamycin analogs. Attachment of a photoswitchable group to rapamycin allowed us to control the configuration of the analog using different wavelengths of light. In one configuration, the analog had high affinity for FKBP and FRB, while in a different (unfavorable) configuration, minimal FKBP and FRB dimerization was observed. In addition to a photoswitchable rapamycin analog, a novel photoswitchable amino acid was synthesized and incorporated into FKBP in an effort to control dimerization via different amino acid side chain configurations. We have shared several of our rapamycin analogs with the scientific community and expect and increasing impact as we are validating the biological function of the new compounds.

 

This project contributed to the training of several graduate students, as well as a postdoctoral fellow. In an effort to increase scientific interest among the community, our graduate students regularly participated in outreach events involving underrepresented minority groups at local summer camps. In particular, our efforts focused on kitchen chemistry, in order to portray the importance that chemistry plays in their everyday lives.
